Posts.Title: Radiated tissue: MRI's inconclusive TeaLoverDenise BrendaK

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2007 04:30PM TeaLoverDenise wrote: I called my oncologist's office and asked them to fax me a copy of my MRI report. I'm glad I did. With regard to my right (post-cancer) breast, the report just says that there is some skin thickening around the nipple region and diffuse strandy changes centrally, but enhancement did not suggest residual malignancy and are presumably related to prior surgery and nonhealing wound. BUT .... the report goes on to say that there is a small focal 5mm enhancinc lesion on the left breast that has kinetic curve analysis of rapid uptake and washout and that "this in and of itself is suspicious." On the last mammogram I had (October 2006) no abnormality was seen in the left breast. The MRI report ends with the suggestion that I obtain a new mammogram and that "if there is no abnormality seen by mammogram, the finding on MR in the setting of a prior history of lumpectomy in the right breast would warrant biopsy [of the left breast]." The nurse at my oncologist's office never mentioned the left breast situation to me. I'm glad I asked for a copy of the report. They are scheduling my mammogram. Scary stuff.
Posts.Title: Radiated tissue: MRI's inconclusive TeaLoverDenise BrendaK
